articles.headline: The Shadow of Steve Jobs in Apple’s Maps Push
articles.snippet: The company’s bundling of its mapping technology with the iPhone 5 brings to mind the Microsoft-Netscape antitrust battles of the 1990s.
articles.abstract: The company’s bundling of its mapping technology with the iPhone 5 brings to mind the Microsoft-Netscape antitrust battles of the 1990s.
articles.lead_paragraph: Steven P. Jobs could hardly have hoped for a better legacy than the performance since his death of Apple, the company he co-founded and dominated. Its revenue, profit and share price have hit records. It’s the world’s largest company by market capitalization.

articles.headline: Avon Chairwoman to Quit Earlier Than Expected
articles.snippet: Andrea Jung, who was pushed out as chief executive last December, had been expected to remain as chairwoman for at least two years.
articles.abstract: Andrea Jung, who was pushed out as chief executive last December, had been expected to remain as chairwoman for at least two years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Andrea Jung, who resigned as chief executive of Avon Products late last year, announced on Friday that she would step down as executive chairwoman at the end of the year, further cutting her ties with a beauty products company for which she long served as its glamorous public face.

articles.headline: Assuring Care of a Family Member With Special Needs
articles.snippet: A confounding thicket of tasks and rules faces people who are trying to sort out the financial side of long-term care for a physically or developmentally disabled family member.
articles.abstract: A confounding thicket of tasks and rules faces people who are trying to sort out the financial side of long-term care for a physically or developmentally disabled family member.
articles.lead_paragraph: With each passing election season, the conversations about the cost of government-provided health care and Social Security get more urgent.

articles.headline: Taming Volatile Raw Data for Jobs Reports
articles.snippet: A source of volatility in the last couple of months — and one of the biggest contributors to the bump in employment in September — was the group between the ages of 20 and 24.
articles.abstract: A source of volatility in the last couple of months — and one of the biggest contributors to the bump in employment in September — was the group between the ages of 20 and 24.
articles.lead_paragraph: 7:32 p.m. | Updated The unemployment rate fell to 7.8 percent in September, its lowest level since President Obama took office. With just a month to go before the election, the news seemed too good to be true, at least for some Mitt Romney supporters.

articles.headline: Pig Farmers Face Pressure on the Size of the Sty
articles.snippet: Some corporate pork buyers are refusing to buy pork derived from farms that use tiny gestation crates, but farmers argue that the crates are for the good of the sow — and consumers.
articles.abstract: Some corporate pork buyers are refusing to buy pork derived from farms that use tiny gestation crates, but farmers argue that the crates are for the good of the sow — and consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: ELDRIDGE, Iowa — Sow 44733 had broken the shoulder of one of her pen mates, rousted another who was huddled in the corner and was chewing on the ear of a third.

articles.headline: California Struggles With High Gas Prices
articles.snippet: With gasoline supplies already tight, a power failure at Exxon Mobil’s Torrance, Calif., refinery on Monday crimped production even further, but normal operations have resumed.
articles.abstract: With gasoline supplies already tight, a power failure at Exxon Mobil’s Torrance, Calif., refinery on Monday crimped production even further, but normal operations have resumed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Drivers in Southern California awoke Friday to find that their gasoline prices had spiked by nearly 20 cents a gallon overnight as a result of fuel shortages caused by a series of refinery disruptions in recent weeks.

articles.headline: Romney Claims of Bipartisanship as Governor Face Challenge
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney did score some successes beyond his health care legislation as governor of Massachusetts, but critics say he never mastered reaching across the aisle.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney did score some successes beyond his health care legislation as governor of Massachusetts, but critics say he never mastered reaching across the aisle.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — He came into office with a mandate to shake things up, an agenda laden with civics-book reforms and a raging fiscal crisis that threatened to torpedo both. He sparred with a hostile legislature and suffered a humiliating setback in the midterm elections. As four years drew to a close, his legacy was blotted by anemic job growth, sagging political popularity and — except for a landmark health care overhaul bill — a record of accomplishment that disappointed many.

articles.headline: Worries Over Defense Department Money for ‘Hackerspaces’
articles.snippet: The financing has prompted criticism that the military’s money could co-opt workshops where hackers gather to build, invent or take apart things in their spare time.
articles.abstract: The financing has prompted criticism that the military’s money could co-opt workshops where hackers gather to build, invent or take apart things in their spare time.
articles.lead_paragraph: This fall, 16 high schools in California started experimental workshops, billed as a kind of “shop class for the 21st century,” that were financed by the federal government. And over the next three years, the $10 million program plans to expand to 1,000 high schools, modeled on the growing phenomenon of “hackerspaces” — community clubhouses where hackers gather to build, invent or take things apart in their spare time.

articles.headline: A Master of Improv, Writing Twitter’s Script
articles.snippet: A comic’s heart beats inside Dick Costolo, the nonconforming chief executive of Twitter who may well hold the key to the company’s success.
articles.abstract: A comic’s heart beats inside Dick Costolo, the nonconforming chief executive of Twitter who may well hold the key to the company’s success.
articles.lead_paragraph: WELCOME to the Dick Costolo Show.

articles.headline: The Muni Bond Market, Mired in Its Past
articles.snippet: Regulators put muni issuers on notice about disclosing basic financial information, but some don’t seem to have gotten the message, and the regulators don’t seem to care.
articles.abstract: Regulators put muni issuers on notice about disclosing basic financial information, but some don’t seem to have gotten the message, and the regulators don’t seem to care.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE $4 trillion market in municipal bonds, which finances American life where it gets lived, is stuck in the Dark Ages. It has been for decades.

articles.headline: They Work Long Hours, but What About Results?
articles.snippet: Often, professionals are judged by the amount of time they spend at the office. But that gauge can be at odds with workplace efficiency.
articles.abstract: Often, professionals are judged by the amount of time they spend at the office. But that gauge can be at odds with workplace efficiency.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT’S 5 p.m. at the office. Working fast, you’ve finished your tasks for the day and want to go home. But none of your colleagues have left yet, so you stay another hour or two, surfing the Web and reading your e-mails again, so you don’t come off as a slacker.

articles.headline: Citing U.S. Fears, Arab Allies Limit Syrian Rebel Aid
articles.snippet: Officials in Saudi Arabia and Qatar said they were withholding heavier weapons in part because of worries by the United States that they could end up in the hands of terrorists.
articles.abstract: Officials in Saudi Arabia and Qatar said they were withholding heavier weapons in part because of worries by the United States that they could end up in the hands of terrorists.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — For months, Saudi Arabia and Qatar have been funneling money and small arms to Syria’s rebels but have refused to provide heavier weapons, like shoulder-fired missiles, that could allow opposition fighters to bring down government aircraft, take out armored vehicles and turn the war’s tide.

articles.headline: Scant Oversight of Drug Maker in Fatal Meningitis Outbreak
articles.snippet: The rising toll has cast a harsh light on the loose regulations that legal experts say allowed a company to sell an unsafe drug to pain clinics.
articles.abstract: The rising toll has cast a harsh light on the loose regulations that legal experts say allowed a company to sell an unsafe drug to pain clinics.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eddie C. Lovelace, a Kentucky judge still on the bench into his late 70s, had a penchant for reciting Shakespeare from memory and telling funny stories in his big, booming voice. But a car accident last spring left him with severe neck pain, and in July and August he sought spinal injections with a steroid medicine for relief.
articles.byline: By Denise Grady, Andrew Pollack and Sabrina Tavernise

articles.headline: Error and Fraud at Issue as Absentee Voting Rises
articles.snippet: Nationwide, mailed ballots now account for nearly 20 percent of votes, yet such ballots are more likely to be compromised, and contested, than those cast in person, statistics show.
articles.abstract: Nationwide, mailed ballots now account for nearly 20 percent of votes, yet such ballots are more likely to be compromised, and contested, than those cast in person, statistics show.
articles.lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — On the morning of the primary here in August, the local elections board met to decide which absentee ballots to count. It was not an easy job.

articles.headline: Disruptions: With a 3-D Printer, Building a Gun With the Push of a Button
articles.snippet: It might sound like science fiction, but 3-D printers are quickly becoming a consumer product, and people are already planning how to print a firearm.
articles.abstract: It might sound like science fiction, but 3-D printers are quickly becoming a consumer product, and people are already planning how to print a firearm.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has long been possible to make a gun at home. But what happens when it no longer takes knowledge and skill to build one?

articles.headline: To Regulate Rapid Traders, S.E.C. Turns to One of Them
articles.snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission is paying a trading firm for software that will give the agency its first real-time window on an increasingly sophisticated stock market.
articles.abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission is paying a trading firm for software that will give the agency its first real-time window on an increasingly sophisticated stock market.
articles.lead_paragraph: RED BANK, N.J. — As billions of shares course through the stock market each day, investors rely on the government to keep up with Wall Street’s rapid-fire traders.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Romney and G.O.P. Make Inroads in Silicon Valley
articles.snippet: While President Obama is widely seen as a friend of the tech industry, and has gotten far more donations, the excitement of his 2008 campaign has ebbed among investors and executives.
articles.abstract: While President Obama is widely seen as a friend of the tech industry, and has gotten far more donations, the excitement of his 2008 campaign has ebbed among investors and executives.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When President Obama makes his latest foray into Silicon Valley on Monday, he will face a technology industry more engaged than ever in the wheeling and dealing of Washington, and much more forthcoming with its political contributions — including, generously, to his rival, Mitt Romney.

articles.headline: Campaigns Use Social Media to Lure Younger Voters
articles.snippet: If the presidential campaigns of 2008 were dipping a toe into social media like Facebook and Twitter, their 2012 versions are well into the deep end.
articles.abstract: If the presidential campaigns of 2008 were dipping a toe into social media like Facebook and Twitter, their 2012 versions are well into the deep end.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2012, it is not enough for candidates to shake some hands, kiss a baby or two and run some TV ads. They also need to be posting funny little animations on the blogging site Tumblr.

articles.headline: Still a Conservative Provocateur, Carlson Angles for Clicks, Not Fights
articles.snippet: Tucker Carlson’s Daily Caller has quadrupled its page views and total audience in two years, and it announced that it became profitable this year.
articles.abstract: Tucker Carlson’s Daily Caller has quadrupled its page views and total audience in two years, and it announced that it became profitable this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: A week ago, Tucker Carlson cued up a video of President Obama that had been sent to him by a source. The video, recorded in 2007 when Mr. Obama was a presidential candidate, showed him speaking to a black audience about “quiet riots” in the black community and the differences in the federal government’s responses to the Sept. 11 attacks and Hurricane Katrina.

articles.headline: With Biden Up Next to Debate, Obama’s Aides Plot Comeback
articles.snippet: Central to the effort by President Obama’s team to recover momentum is a renewed effort to win the three remaining debates, starting with Thursday’s vice-presidential face-off.
articles.abstract: Central to the effort by President Obama’s team to recover momentum is a renewed effort to win the three remaining debates, starting with Thursday’s vice-presidential face-off.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s campaign is working feverishly to restore its momentum after a lackluster debate performance last week, an effort that began with a conference call 10 minutes before the debate even ended and led to new advertisements, a rewritten stump speech, a carefully timed leak and a reversal of months-old strategy.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Trip Gabriel

articles.headline: The Patent, Used as a Sword
articles.snippet: Alongside the impressive technology advances of the last two decades, many see a destructive use of software patents corrupting the marketplace for ideas.
articles.abstract: Alongside the impressive technology advances of the last two decades, many see a destructive use of software patents corrupting the marketplace for ideas.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Apple announced last year that all iPhones would come with a voice-activated assistant named Siri, capable of answering spoken questions, Michael Phillips’s heart sank.
articles.byline: By Charles Duhigg and Steve Lohr

articles.headline: Spinning Gaffes Into Gags: Live From New York, It’s Debate Night
articles.snippet: NBC, usually protective about the process of putting together Saturday Night Live, allowed access to the show’s writers, stars and rehearsals this week as they prepared their debate sketch.
articles.abstract: NBC, usually protective about the process of putting together Saturday Night Live, allowed access to the show’s writers, stars and rehearsals this week as they prepared their debate sketch.
articles.lead_paragraph: All last week, Lorne Michaels, the creator and longtime executive producer of “Saturday Night Live” was working the phone trying to nail down a visit to the show from either of this year’s presidential candidates. By late Friday, it looked like it wouldn’t happen, at least for this last week.

articles.headline: YouTube to Serve Niche Tastes by Adding Channels
articles.snippet: YouTube, now carrying more polished output, will announce more original channels to the 100 it has introduced in the last year.
articles.abstract: YouTube, now carrying more polished output, will announce more original channels to the 100 it has introduced in the last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: A visit to YouTube these days shows so many professionally produced channels that it could be confused with a TV guide. There are channels for ABC News, Taylor Swift, Nike Football, America’s Test Kitchen and the Obama for America campaign.

articles.headline: Corruption Is Seen as a Drain on Italy’s South
articles.snippet: A 300-mile highway in Calabria has yet to be finished after decades of work, and critics see it as the rotten fruit of a jobs-for-votes culture.
articles.abstract: A 300-mile highway in Calabria has yet to be finished after decades of work, and critics see it as the rotten fruit of a jobs-for-votes culture.
articles.lead_paragraph: REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy — Italy’s A3 highway, begun in the 1960s and still not finished, starts outside Naples in the ancient hill town of Salerno and ends, rather unceremoniously, 300 miles farther south as a local street in downtown Reggio Calabria.

articles.headline: Romney Strives to Stand Apart in Global Policy
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney has yet to explain how he would conduct policy toward the Middle East, or to resolve deep ideological rifts within the Republican Party.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney has yet to explain how he would conduct policy toward the Middle East, or to resolve deep ideological rifts within the Republican Party.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mitt Romney intensified his efforts Monday to draw a sharp contrast with President Obama on national security in the presidential campaign’s closing stages, portraying Mr. Obama as having mishandled the tumult in the Arab world and having left the nation exposed to a terrorist attack in Libya.

articles.headline: U.S. Panel Cites Risks in Chinese Equipment
articles.snippet: The House Intelligence Committee said telecommunications equipment from Huawei Technologies and ZTE could be used for spying in the United States.
articles.abstract: The House Intelligence Committee said telecommunications equipment from Huawei Technologies and ZTE could be used for spying in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the latest development to highlight the sensitive terrain that the United States and China are navigating on economic issues, a House committee issued a blistering bipartisan report on Monday that accused two of China’s largest telecommunications companies of being arms of the government that had stolen intellectual property from American companies and could potentially spy on Americans.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt, Keith Bradsher and Christine Hauser
